name: Matt Ferreira
comment info:
I noticed that the most consumed food by Americans today is chicken, and beef comes in as second. The lowest consumed food (on the graph) today is yogurt, which has gained much traction compared to its absence in the 1960s. While chicken has been on a rather steady rise for decades, beef was actually consumed far more than chicken in the 1970s, but quickly declined and was surpassed by chicken in the 1990s.

I wonder why the consumption of beef has declined so much since the 1970s, and why Americans have been consuming chicken more and more. Could it be due to vegetarian movements, or simply resource costs? Is it because chicken takes less time to cultivate and requires less resources, like the groundwater usage in the second graph(therefore also being cheaper)?

It’s interesting how much chicken and beef have become a staple in the American diet. The amount of water being used can also be concerning, as water is also a vital resource for many energy processes, and basic human survival and necessities. This raises awareness for where the foods from our diets come from and how much it costs to create them.

Headline:
Feeding America: The Heavy Toll of Foods on Our Water Stores

name: Orin Lallif
comment info: Americans eat such an unsustainable diet it’s insane how nobody does anything to change this. Have you ever walked into the average public school cafeteria. Every single meal has either pork, beef, or chicken as the main source of protein and calories. This needs to change. Not only is meat not healthy for people in the long run, the quality of life of these animals is absolutely terrible. Factory farming is a disgusting way to treat living creatures. We stuff them in tight cages and inject them with hormones and antibiotics that end up in the food we feed our children. And these staple meats aren’t good for the environment either. The demand for cheap, mass produced chicken, beef and pork had pit a strain on our natural environment: It drains groundwater leaving the soil stripped of nutrients, pollutes nearby water sources and spreads disease among animals and humans. The healthier, more sustainable, and more humane alternative is to cut back on the meat. I understand completely eliminating meat from the American diet is impossible, but nobody even tries to look for moderation. There doesn’t need to be one or the other, balance is what we must strive for.

Why do cheese and yogurt require less water? If most individuals switch to a vegetarian diet, how would this affect the cost in water of popular foods? What foods would become more popular?  If Americans stopped consuming meat, how would this impact the environment?  What can humans eat that does not require a lot of water? If humans continue overconsuming meat, what will happen to the environment in 2060? How much water is needed to produce fish? 

This relates to me as I am a meat-eater and enjoy burgers, steak, and chicken. However, may be best to consume less meat and eat foods that require less water in order to help the planet.  It was interesting to look at food from the perspective of production as I did not know that large amounts of water are used to produce common foods. Water is important, not only for drinking, but also for the production and growing of foods, so it should be conserved as much as possible.

Chicken Is Bacon the World Crazy

name: Isabella P. AOSE
comment info:
The first graph shows how America's diet has changed from 1920-2020. This graph tracks various produce (chicken, yogurt, beef, pork, and cheese) in terms of pounds per person. The second graph tracks how much water it takes to produce these foods. The first graph shows the popularity of chicken has skyrocketed from under 20 pounds per person in the 1920s to over 80 pounds per person in 2020. It can be concluded this is because farming chickens takes up less water that other meats such as pork and beef as shown in the second graph. In the past few decades, Americans have become more aware of environmental concerns. There is a direct correlation between this new ideology and the increasing popularity of chicken. As Americans aim to conserve water, they are producing more chicken rather than beef and pork because it takes up less water. Cheese is another product that has become popular. I wonder why cheese takes up so much less water to produce than beef if they come from the same animal (cows). I also wondered why yogurt only began gaining popularity in the 1960's. The internet said yogurt only began being sold in America in 1942. In the 1950s, yogurt began gaining popularity because it was ruled a "health food". This graph relates to me because these products have extremely high water consumption which has detrimental effects on the environment. The longer we ignore this damage for the profits of large businesses, the worse this issue is going to get. 
"Foods vs. Facts"

This graph, and its supporting graph, shows the rise of food production and how this food is starting to affect groundwater. Chicken consumption, for example, has drastically increased for the average American person. However, chickens, before they are killed for food, are fed by soybeans. The amount of soybean having to be produced has hurt the groundwater supply across states like Arkansas. In all, chicken production has an intake of 410 gallons of water per pound. I wonder if the production and consumption of chicken keeps rising, like it has been since the 1940s, how will this continue to negatively impact places such as Arkansas? Is there a time when their groundwater supply may run out? In my community, most people eat organic foods and meat, which is better for the environment. While our consumption harms the groundwater supply, it is better for the environment in terms of less gas release and waste management. 
“Are Chickens Stealing Our Water?”

name: Mo
comment info: There is a little bit of information missing about the first graph, namely the duration in time for each contributing data point. I will assume it is the annual consumption of each staple in pounds per person. The line is a running average over five years, which smooths it out a bit and makes it easier to see long term trends. Chicken, cheese, and yogurt have gone up a lot but beef and pork have not declined nearly as much, in other words, it looks like people are either many more pounds of these protein-rich staples per year nowadays than earlier. I wonder if there are other staples, not on this graph, that have significant reductions in consumption. If not, this graph implies that the number of calories that people consume has gone up significantly and if that is the case, this graph may show a nice correlation with mean weight, or BMI, of the population over time. If there are other staples that people eat significantly less of, it would be interesting to know what their water needs are. Also, the first graph is per person, which is great, but the population has also increased. So not only has this protein intake increased per person but even more so on an absolute scale because population has increased. Lots of interesting questions to ask about these data and what the implications are!

replies.name: N
replies.comment info:
@Mo
I first look to see if the baseline numbers start at zero, which this graph does for pounds of protein consumed. (If a baseline does not start at zero it can show much smaller percentage changes, which has its good and bad points)
The next thing I look at is what is being measured and how. Is the protein cooked or raw, dry weight or after adding additives and “extra water” and brine to increase the weight?  This info should be in the written section, and how the measurement may be changing over the years. I agree with the earlier comment that the amount pound per person also needs per year or month, we both assumed that it would be per year. 
Now I wonder who is being measured. Adults, kids, growing teenage boys?  Did this change over the variation in years. Or is it measuring grocery store sales and average population, which has changed.  

I would have like to see a total protein line on the graph to show how much more animal protein we are eating per person.  Why did chicken increase so much but the beef and pork stayed relatively stable rather than decrease.
